Award.AwardTitle: Characterization of fault zone sediments from borehole logging data at the Nankai Trough (NanTroSEIZE Project)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
The study proposed is for a MARGINS postdoctoral researcher. The postdoctoral researcher will integrate downhole log data and the rock samples obtained from an Integrated Ocean Drilling Program drill hole. The long term aim of the work is to be able to identify sediment types using the log data when no core samples are available. This information will be used to assess how sediments change as they are subducted, especially in the region where earthquakes occur. Development of a method to use log data fully is important to the broad geosciences community.
Broader Impacts
The broader impacts include the career advancement and training of an early career female scientist

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project is one part of the Nankai Trough Seismogenic Zone experiment, or "NanTroSEIZE," a major international research project involving drilling into, sampling, and instrumenting a submarine fault zone that harbors devastating tsunamis and earthquakes in the Nankai Trough region offshore Japan. This location has been intensively studied in recent years by seismologists and geologists as a “natural laboratory” that typifies the offshore subduction faults that present tsunami hazards globally. The NanTroSEIZE drilling has been done as part of the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP), using the scientific drilling vessel Chikyu, operated by Japan as part of this international collaboration involving scientists from more than 20 countries. While drilling, sensitive geophysical tools were lowered into the boreholes to measure properties of the rocks and sediments in their “native habitat” hundreds to thousands of meters deep beneath the sea bed.

   At the Nankai Trough, the main earthquake and tsunami-causing fault is thought to be locked up at depth of greater than 5 kilometers and building up strain that will eventually cause the next large earthquake there. At shallower depths, it is thought to release strain in smaller, more frequent events or by continuously slipping or “creeping.” The transition between these modes of fault behaviour as it gets deeper is of great interest to earthquake researchers, as it may be the key to understanding why some faults are more dangerous than others. The strength of this fault – how easily it could move – is believed to be controlled in large part by the water content of the sediments in and beneath the fault. In the IODP NanTroSEIZE project, a series of boreholes have been drilled that sampled the sediments and rocks entering the subduction zone and those caught up in the convergence zone between the two plates.

   This NSF-sponsored project, as part of the MARGINS program, provided funds for a two–year study by postdoctoral scholar Dr. Joanne Tudge. She used the geophysical logging data measured down the boreholes with sophisticated logging-while-drilling instruments to characterise the physical state of the sediments, rocks, and attendant pore fluids that are entering the subduction zone, and those within the “accretionary wedge” –  the large undersea build-up of sediments and rocks scraped off the underlying plate during millions of years of plate tectonic motion.  Two of the main properties of the sediments are the seismic wave velocity (how fast sound can travel through the rocks), and the porosity (the amount of space in the rocks filled with seawater). The relationship between these two properties is intrinsically linked to the geological history of the sediments, and can be used to infer the stress conditions within fault zones and in surrounding rocks. Dr. Tudge investigated how this relationship evolves for increasingly deformed sediments in the Nankai Trough setting. Using the borehole geophysical data of only the entering sediments and rocks she established the relationship between seismic velocity and porosity. This relationship allows us to use the seismic velocity data to estimate the amount of fluid pressure, stress, and stored pore water within and beneath this fault at depth. These key measurements can in turn be used to estimate the strength of the fault zone and ultimately the likelihood of its rupture in a major earthquake. This work is thus a part of the broader effort to further our understanding of what causes faults to slip, why some earthquakes are larger than others, and especially what factors control the scale of resulting tsunamis.
